userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], J. Walter Thompson Company. Chicago Office. Non-Proprietary Research Reports, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The J. Walter Thompson Company. Chicago Office. Non-Proprietary Research Reports were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 1999.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Encoded by Lynn E. Eaton; Joshua A. Kaiser
Materials may not have been ordered and described beyond their original condition.
This collection is unprocessed: materials may not have been ordered and described beyond their original condition.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The J. Walter Thompson Company (JWT) was founded in New York, N.Y., in 1864, and is one of the world's largest advertising agencies.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection created by the JWT Chicago Office Information Center as a reference and research tool for business use. The term non-proprietary is JWT's term for research prepared or collected by the company but not on behalf of specific clients. The collection includes market and consumer research reports arranged alphabetically by subject. A small number of items represent JWT research done, but most were created by market research firms (e.g., Yankelovich, Elmo Roper and Associates), cable TV stations (e.g., MTV Networks), or magazines (e.g., Seventeen, Good Housekeeping), and others. Topics include consumer demographic analyses for the United States, especially of food and beverage products and restaurant services. Marketing to women is a major subject; there is also information on marketing to men, baby boomers, teens, and children. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising and Marketing History. (02-256)
